title: Registration of different phases of contrast-enhanced CT/MRI data for computer-assisted liver surgery planning: Evaluation of state-of-the-art methods
author: Lange T.; Wenckebach T.H.; Lamecker H.; Seebass M.; Hünerbein M.; Eulenstein S.; Gebauer B.; Schlag P.M.
journal: International Journal of Medical Robotics and Computer Assisted Surgery
abstract: Accurate registration of different phases of contrast-enhanced CT/MRI data is essential for computer-assisted liver surgery planning. This paper evaluates state-of-the-art registration methods for aligning multiphase contrast-enhanced liver images. We compare intensity-based and feature-based approaches, assessing their accuracy, robustness, and computational efficiency on clinical datasets. Our results demonstrate that while intensity-based methods achieve higher accuracy in homogeneous regions, feature-based methods offer better performance in areas with significant anatomical changes due to contrast enhancement. The study provides insights into the strengths and limitations of current registration techniques, guiding the selection of appropriate methods for clinical applications in liver surgery planning.

title: Evaluation of microleakage of composite resin restorations by an electrochemical technique: The impedance methodology
author: Pradelle-Plasse N.; Wenger F.; Picard B.; Colon P.
abstract: The aim of this study was to evaluate the microleakage of composite resin restorations by an electrochemical technique, the impedance methodology. Class V cavities were prepared on the buccal surfaces of 30 extracted human premolars and restored with a composite resin. The specimens were subjected to thermocycling and then immersed in an electrolyte solution. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed to assess the microleakage at the tooth-restoration interface. The results showed that the impedance values correlated with the degree of microleakage, indicating that the EIS technique is a sensitive and non-destructive method for evaluating the sealing ability of composite resin restorations. This method could be a valuable tool for in vitro studies of restorative materials and techniques.

title: Non-decay type fast-setting calcium phosphate cement: Setting behaviour in calf serum and its tissue response
author: Miyamoto Y.; Ishikawa K.; Takechi M.; Yuasa M.; Kon M.; Nagayama M.; Asaoka K.
abstract: The setting behaviour of a non-decay type fast-setting calcium phosphate cement (CPC) was investigated in calf serum and its tissue response was evaluated in vivo. The cement was prepared by mixing tetracalcium phosphate and dicalcium phosphate anhydrous powders with a 2% sodium phosphate solution. The setting time of the cement in calf serum was significantly shorter than that in distilled water. The compressive strength of the cement set in calf serum was also higher than that set in distilled water. Histological examination after implantation in rat femurs showed that the cement was biocompatible and was gradually resorbed and replaced by new bone tissue. These results suggest that the non-decay type fast-setting CPC has potential for clinical applications as a bone substitute material.

title: Failure mode of dental restorative materials under Hertzian indentation
author: Wang Y.; Darvell B.W.
abstract: The failure mode of dental restorative materials under Hertzian indentation was investigated to understand their mechanical behavior and durability. Using a spherical indenter, various dental restorative materials were subjected to controlled loading to simulate occlusal contact stresses. The study analyzed crack initiation and propagation patterns, identifying critical stress thresholds leading to material failure. Results indicated that brittle materials exhibited cone cracking and radial cracking, while more resilient composites showed different failure mechanisms. These findings provide insights into the design and selection of restorative materials with improved resistance to occlusal forces, contributing to enhanced clinical performance and longevity of dental restorations.
